title: final say brexit petition second referendum peoples vote signatures eu poll
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsMore than a million people backed&nbspthe call for a public vote on Theresa May’s Brexit deal in just three monthsClick to followIndy PoliticsThe Independent’s petition for a Final Say referendum has been revealed as the most popular UK petition all year, as new polling shows the&nbspmajority of voters feel they have been cut out of the&nbspBrexit&nbspprocess.More than a million people backed the call for a public vote on Theresa May’s Brexit deal in just three months, after deadlock&nbspin talks with Brussels&nbspand growing concerns over the prospect of a&nbspno-deal Brexit.Change.org, the world’s largest petition platform, said&nbspBrexit was dominating&nbsppublic opinion and&nbspThe Independent’s Final Say petition was the biggest UK campaign it&nbsphad hosted in 2018.Everyone feels cut out the Brexit process – even LeaversIt comes as a&nbspnew poll by&nbspthe influential site found that more than 85 per cent of voters felt they had been ignored over&nbspthe Brexit strategy, compared to just&nbsp7.4 per cent who said they had been adequately consulted.Change.org&nbspsurveyed more than 89,000&nbspusers in the UK between October 31 and November 5, of which 63 per cent backed Remain, a quarter voted Leave&nbspand the remainder either did not vote or chose not to say.Half of respondents believe their MP had failed to represent them properly over Brexit, compared to 16 per cent who said their MP had represented them fairly. A third of those who replied were undecided.&nbspThe majority (63.3 per cent) backed a second referendum when asked how the government could give people a say on the terms of Britain’s exit from the bloc, while 10.9 per cent suggested a public consultation.About 10 per cent said they trust the government to do a good job, and 7.4 per cent said the UK should just leave the EU.Kajal Odedra, executive director of change.org UK, said people feel “bombarded but gagged by Brexit”, regardless of whether they voted to leave or remain in the European Union.EU to decide whether Brits will need visas in event of no-deal BrexitVoters in most vulnerable Tory seats 'back fresh Brexit vote'Every day takes us closer to giving the people the final say on BrexitThornberry says Labour could still back Final Say Brexit referendumCorbyn rejects calls for Final Say referendum, despite Labour backlashJohnson insists May can be forced into Final Say referendum on BrexitWriting exclusively for The Independent, Ms Odedra said: “The choices the government makes in negotiations are critical.&nbsp“But they are being made far away from the public with no consultation whatsoever.&nbsp“When we asked change.org users, only 7 per cent of those polled felt they have been given a chance for their voices to be heard since the referendum.“And 85 per cent felt they didn’t have any say in shaping the government’s Brexit strategy.”Leave voters were more likely to feel heard by ministers at about 23 per cent, while only 1.4 per cent of Remain voters said they had been listened to, according to the poll.Young people were also more likely to feel ignored than older voters, the findings show, with just 8.3 per cent of 16 to 24-year-olds reporting that they believe their voices are being heard.Around a quarter of over-65s said they felt listened to, compared to 20 per cent of those aged 55 to 64, and 10.5 per cent of 25 to 34-year-olds.It comes after a special parliamentary event heard that&nbspmore people back a fresh referendum than oppose one in all of the 67 most marginal Tory seats.The YouGov survey of 25,000 people&nbspalso found that a majority of voters in the Labour constituencies that voted Leave in 2016 now back a fresh referendum, by an average of 59 per cent in favour compared to 41 per cent against.It also comes as more than 3,000 people were expected to attend a major rally in London to urge&nbspMPs&nbspto reject a bad Brexit deal.Cross-party MPs have backed the call,&nbspincluding Tory Jo Johnson, who resigned from government last week over Theresa May’s Brexit strategy, Labour’s David Lammy and SNP&nbspWestminster leader Ian Blackford.Liberal Democrat MP&nbspLayla Moran, who backs the Best for Britain campaign,&nbspsaid: “No one voted for this pathetic little deal which actually hands over our sovereignty, making the UK a rule taker rather than a rule maker. It is the opposite of taking back control.”Caroline Lucas, former Green party co-leader,&nbspadded: “The only solution is to take the final decision out of the hands of deadlocked politicians, away from the backroom deals, and give it back to the public with a People’s Vote.“On Brexit, it’s clear we have a parliament in stalemate that can’t deliver a clear choice for the future. IndependentA Chinese city has ordered members of a Muslim minority group to turn themselves in to authorities if they observe practices such as abstention from alcohol.Hami city government in the far-western Xinjiang region said people “poisoned by extremism, terrorism and separatism” would be treated leniently if they surrendered within the next 30 days.The move comes as Beijing faces increasing international scrutiny over its treatment of the Uighur Muslim minority and other ethnic groups living in Xinjiang.China forcing ethnic Uighurs to serve as intelligence assetsChina urged to close mass detention camps for Uighur MuslimsChina claims Uighur Muslims grateful to be held in internment campsInside China’s ‘re-education centres’ for Uighur MuslimsChina's Uighur minority shackled by technology as thousands detainedAs many as a million Uighurs are thought to have been rounded up and placed in “re-education” centres, in what China claims is a clampdown on religious extremism.The government message to Muslims in Xinjiang warned actions from contact with overseas terror groups to conservative Islamic behaviour would require iniduals to turn themselves in.Those who reject government-provided housing, alcohol or cigarettes on the basis they are&nbsp“haram”, or forbidden by Islam, were ordered to notify authorities.Advocating people live their lives entirely in accordance with the Quran or preventing dancing at weddings were also listed as problematic behaviours.“All iniduals involved in terrorist crimes and poisoned by the 'three evil forces' are urged to surrender themselves to the judicial organs within 30 days and to confess and hand over the facts of your crime,“ the notice said.China has for decades sought to stamp out Islam in order&nbspto maintain its influence on Xinjiang, where almost half of the 24 million-strong population are from Uighur or other Muslim minority backgrounds.Authorities claim the region is under serious threat of attacks by Islamist extremists aiming to stir up tensions between the ethnic Han Chinese majority and the Muslim population.&nbspIn August, a United Nations human rights panel said it had received many credible reports that a million or more Uighurs and other minorities are being held in what resembles a “massive internment camp that is shrouded in secrecy”.China insists it is not enforcing arbitrary detention and political re-education.However, those who have spent time in the centres say they were forced to undergo an intensive indoctrination programme, urged to renounce Islam and title: brexit deal theresa may european council eu summit donald tusk draft agreement
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis: Officials in Brussels hope representatives of&nbspthe remaining EU members&nbspwill&nbspnot seek to reopen negotiations, says&nbspJon StoneClick to followThe IndependentEU leaders will meet in Brussels on Sunday to sign off the Brexit deal struck with Theresa May, but you could be forgiven for asking what the point of the gathering is.After all, barring a last minute climbdown by Theresa May’s detractors back home, the parliamentary arithmetic in Westminster looks fairly certain to defeat the plan.Still, the 27 countries will go through the motions this weekend, unless there’s some kind of intervention to oust the prime minister during the week. It would be a huge upset if they did not sign the agreement.The Daily Mail and the  could save us from a hard BrexitThere will not be any negotiation on the withdrawal agreement and its controversial backstop – that, as far as the EU is concerned, is settled. Many countries have said as much publicly, in the face of cabinet Brexiteers demanding a rethink.But the second part of the deal, the future relationship, is far from sealed. If anything, EU states believe their negotiators might have given away too much to Britain: some are unhappy about concessions given with little in return, and want quid pro quos like guaranteed access to British waters for their fishing fleets.If there are changes there, things could get even trickier for the prime minister at home – but these are real countries fighting for their own interests, not fantasy negotiating partners only committed to making things easy for the prime minister.None of the details for the summit are finalised yet, with an agenda set to be released later this week. We’re not sure at this point whether actual negotiation will take place at it, or whether it will just be a glorified rubber stamp. Brussels is known to favour the latter.I was on holiday during the Brexit chaos – what did I miss?Legally, the summit has to take place, because only the European Council – that is the 27 leaders meeting together in Brussels – can sign off the deal and make the political declaration about the future relationship.Those in Brussels and other EU capitals do not like being seen to “meddle” in British politics, precisely because they know how poorly they are perceived.They mostly stayed out of the referendum, they accepted the result, and they have mostly declined to call for a rerun or anything to that effect.But it is possible some may break the habit of a lifetime at the gathering and urge British members of parliament to back the deal. If they do not do it directly, they might apply pressure through other means – perhaps by warning of the prospect of no deal if it is voted down.This will be a difficult sell, however. Donald Tusk, the president of the European Council, said as recently as last week that Brexit could be stopped if Britain wanted. If the deal is voted down, staying in is still an option. And there is clearly not a majority for a no-deal departure in the House of Commons.But despite conspiracy theories from both some Brexiteers and the odd&nbspRemainer, everyone around the summit table will want a deal – just not necessarily at any cost.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsIsraeli tourism minister branded move 'the most wretched of wretched capitulations to the boycott efforts'Click to followThe IndependentAirbnb properties in the Jewish West Bank settlement of Dolev are among those which will no longer be listed on the rental company's website Home-renting company Airbnb Inc has said it will remove listings in Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank, a move Israel called a “wretched capitulation” to boycotters and Palestinians hailed as a step towards peace.The decision, affecting some 200 listings, would take effect in the coming days, Airbnb said.Israel captured the West Bank in a 1967 war. Its settlements there are considered illegal by most world powers.Palestinians deem the settlements, and the military presence needed to protect them, to be obstacles to their goal of establishing a state. Israel disputes this.Israel’s plan to demolish West Bank village ‘could be war crime’“We concluded that we should remove listings in Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank that are at the core of the dispute between Israelis and Palestinians,” Airbnb said on its website.“Our hope is that someday sooner rather than later, a framework is put in place where the entire global community is aligned so there will be a resolution to this historic conflict and a clear path forward for everybody to follow.”Palestinians and their supporters had long lobbied Airbnb to delist the settlements. Israel strongly opposes such calls for boycotts, which it considers a biased approach to the conflict.Israeli tourism minister Yariv Levin called Airbnb’s move “the most wretched of wretched capitulations to the boycott efforts”.Speaking on Israel’s Channel 13 television, he said Israel was not told of the decision in advance and that it would respond by backing lawsuits by settlement listers against Airbnb in US courts.Waleed Assraf, head of a Palestinian anti-settlement group run by the umbrella Palestine Liberation Organisation, welcomed Airbnb’s decision. title: angela merkel emmanuel macron euro eurozone budget
story: Bruno Le Maire, France&rsquos finance minister, and his German counterpart Olaf Scholz told reporters plans were &ldquomoving in the right direction to see a common eurozone budget, which they hope to pass by 2021.Le Maire and Scholz hope the a joint budget for all 19 eurozone countries would help stabilise the currency and allow it to more easily absorb economic shocks.However the budget would have to be signed off by all EU countries, some of whom are putting up resistance to the Franco-German alliance.French President Emmanuel Macron has said the &ldquogreater convergence would help the continent&rsquos currency.                Eurozone WARNING: Mario Draghi warns of growth outlook uncertaintyDuring his presidential campaign he argued for such a budget to &ldquoseveral percentage points of GDP, the Financial Times reported.However Dutch finance minister Wopke Hoekstra as well as non-euro states are hesitant as to how the plan would help their economies.Following a meeting of EU finance ministers, Mr Macron said: &ldquoThe lack of convergence between national economies is not sustainable over the long term for a single monetary union.The convergence plan is a central element of Mr Macron&rsquos policy to help the single currency fight future crises and the French president will have been boosted after a number of EU finance ministers backed the plan.French Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire and German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz defend eurozone plan (Image: REUTERS)At a Brussels meeting yesterday, the finance ministers supported draft plans which would operate in the framework of the wider EU budget.Mr Scholz told reporters the scheme would &ldquohelp us to support the convergence of the eurozone and all the other things that are important to our common future.However a number of EU countries, led by the Netherlands, are reluctant to get behind Paris and Berlin&rsquos idea.Denmark, Finland, Poland, Hungary and Austria say they would prefer to see EU spending cut rather than increased.                Italy is holding its people HOSTAGE! EU nations unite to blast budg...France and German leaders hope to introduce a common eurozone budget (Image: )Dutch finance minister Woke Hoekstra raised concerns, telling reporters his government questioned the &ldquoadded value of the budget.Mr Hoekstra said: &ldquoThe need for such a budget is less than convincing.&ldquoIt is unclear how this will help and why this would be in the interest of Dutch citizens.Dutch finance minister Wopke Hoekstra (right) has told Mr Le Maire his country might not back plan (Image: )&ldquoIf this is not in the interest of the Netherlands or the Dutch taxpayer then we are out.Meanwhile an independent Brussels-based economic think tank has warned the complexity of a common eurozone budget could cause problems for the bloc.Guntram Wolff, director of the Bruegel institution told the FT: &ldquoI think it&rsquos going to be small and difficult to operate.Eurozone leaders are set to finalise their position on the budget at a summit next month.

title: The queen prince philip wedding anniversary royal family news latest pictures
story: The Queen and Prince Philip have been married for 71 years  (Image:  )The royal couple&rsquos blissful marriage has gone from strength to strength over 71 years which has seen Elizabeth transform from Princess to Queen, have four children, eight grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. When a then Princess Elizabeth&rsquos father King George VI gave his blessing for the couple&rsquos marriage in 1946, Prince Philip admitted he had &ldquofallen in love completely and unreservedly. The prince&rsquos undying love for the future monarch would lead him to sacrifice his military career after he vowed to act as the future monarch&rsquos &ldquoeyes and ears when the pair tied the knot at Westminster Abbey on November 20, 1947.&nbspPhilip had hoped to enjoy a life overseas in high command for the Royal Navy before his royal duties got in the way.&nbsp                Why Kate Middleton could snub her family this Christmas                71 years in pics: The Queen and Prince Philip celebrate anniversaryBut when it became clear his father-in-law King George VI was in ill health, the Duke resigned as a Royal Navy commander in 1951.The Duke instead threw himself into &ldquomodernising the royal family to overcome the disappointment of the premature loss of his professional career in the Royal Navy after Elizabeth was crowned Queen of the country.Royal expert Richard Fitzwillams previously told Express: &ldquoPhilip would have far preferred a naval career than to be in a supporting role.READ MORE:&nbspThe Queen and Prince Philip celebrate 71 years in pictures&nbspThe Queen and Philip were engaged in summer 1946 while they were staying at Balmoral (Image:  )Prince Philip joined the Navy from school in 1939 aged 18 and went on to serve with distinction in the Mediterranean.He also saw battle in the Second World War and many royal insiders tipped him to go all the way in the senior service and become its chief or First Sea Lord.Philip, who is now 97, was formally made a British prince in 1957 by his wife, after he became the Baron Greenwich, Earl of Merioneth and Duke of Edinburgh just before his wedding to the Queen.And after nearly seven decades by the side of his wife Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip certainly made his mark, only retiring at the grand old age of 96 in August last year.                Sarah Ferguson: Fergie's plan for SECRET meeting with the Queen                How Meghan and Harry 'stole the show' in Australia like young CharlesThe Queen and her husband have enjoyed 71 years of blissful marriage  (Image:  )He has since been seen in public on rare occasions, opting to retreat to the family&rsquos home on the Sandringham estate in Norfolk instead.Philip was most recently seen at his granddaughter Princess Eugenie&rsquos Royal Wedding to Jack Brooksbank in October.The Duke and the Queen share four children, eight grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren, soon to be eight when Meghan Markle gives birth to her royal baby next year.The couple will mark their wedding anniversary at home in private after the Queen, 92, attends an official engagement at the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors in London to mark its own 150th anniversary.The Queen and Philip were seen in public at Princess Eugenie's Royal Wedding  (Image:  )The love story of Philip and Elizabeth, who are distant cousins, began in 1939 when the young princess was just 13-years-old.The couple met during a royal visit to his naval college in Dartmouth. It was love at first sight and they started to write to each other.Dashing, blond-haired, athletic 18-year-old Philip is said to have caught her eye as he entertained her by jumping over tennis nets.Elizabeth was just 21 and Philip, who had renounced his Greek royal title and become a naturalised British subject, was 26 when the pair became engaged.It has been suggested that they became unofficially engaged in summer 1946 while they were staying at Balmoral.

story: Prominent Brexiteer MP David Davis has called for Theresa May to put her draft withdrawal agreement to MPs to vote down, which will then allow Britain to go back to the negotiating table with the Brussels bloc. Mr Davis told Bloomberg: &ldquoIf I were giving her advice, I mean, the Chief Whip will tell her what the odds are. But, if I were giving her advice, I&rsquod say &lsquoput this proposal to the House of Commons straight away&rsquo.                Markets NOT PREPARED for no-deal Brexit, analyst warns                MP warns of DANGEROUS consequences of May's SURRENDER dealMr Davis claimed the deal does not have to go to Brussels first, adding: &ldquoIt has been agreed with the Commission. It is agreed with her negotiators with her. Why do you need to go to Brussels first?&ldquoWhy not come straight to the House of Commons? Because if she goes to Brussels and they all say &lsquoyes fine we like this&rsquo and comes back and is defeated in the House. What does that do for you?&ldquoThe difficulty now, and I think this is what is driving the campaign for letters, is we are going to run out of time.Mr Davis said it is likely that Parliament will &ldquoemphatically vote down the controversial agreement reached between EU and UK negotiators.Brexit news: David Davis said Theresa May should immediately do MPs vote on deal (Image: Bloomberg&bull)He added: &ldquoIt won&rsquot be sort of lost by a couple of votes. I think it will be lost by a large number of votes. Then she goes back to Brussels and says &lsquoI can&rsquot deliver what you have asked for&rsquo.&ldquoAnd then they have got to choose. Do they want no deal or do they want a deal? Whatever they say today, they will decide they want a deal.The Government published the 585-page Brexit withdrawal agreement and seven-page future relationship declaration on Wednesday and have since faced an array of government resignations.The&nbspresignations include two Cabinet ministers, two junior ministers, two ministerial aides and the Conservative party's vice chairman.Dominic Raab resigned from his position as Brexit Secretary citing concerns over an indefinite backstop agreement to avoid a hard Irish border and Nothern Ireland remaining under EU regulations.Esther McVey also announced she was resigning as Work and Pensions Secretary on Thursday as she could not defend a deal which meant the UK handing over control to the EU.It is understood around 24 MPs have submitted letters to the backbench 1922 Committee &ndash still well short of the 48 required to trigger a leadership contest.Members of the European Research Group (ERG) spoke with the Prime Minister at Downing Street on Monday, hours after the group published a scathing attack on her Brexit plan.In its critique of the deal, the ERG said the terms on offer would not actually see the UK leave the EU and consign Britain to the status of a &ldquovassal state.

story: Appearing on World Order 2018, an Amazon Prime documentary by TV host Vladimir Solovjev, the Russian President discussed topics rarely answered by world leaders. title: eu army terrible mistake
story: But there’s something rather wonderful about Donald Trump’s ability to speak the truth, with no frills attached.And not care who he p***es off. Quite right.And he’s right, too, that the EU nations do not pull their weight when it comes to funding the real alliance against our real enemies, Nato.They all like to snipe from the sidelines at the USA.And resent the Americans for their power, influence and success.And for bailing them out of the last war.But then they expect the yanks to spend vast amounts of money protecting them all.Germany, one of the richest countries in the world, spends only . per cent of its GDP on forces for Nato. That is as pathetic as it is typical.The French themselves spend only . per cent.We’re second only to the Americans in our spending — but even then I would argue that it’s not enough.Our Armed Forces have been cut to the bone over the past two decades.Would we be able to retake the Falkland Islands now,Argentina invaded  I doubt it.The truth is that Nato is the one alliance of which we should be glad to be a member.It is an alliance of largely civilised, largely democratic countries which has held fast against tyrants, despots and warmongers for  years.Most notably, of course, the Cold War, in which the Soviet Union was defeated without a shot being fired.But now Trump is getting a bit tired of Nato because the US always has to spend, spend, spend.And with the Europeans thinking again of having an EU army there are many who think the days of Nato are numbered.That would be a terrible mistake.An EU army to replace Nato It would be bureau­cratic, incompetent and short-funded.And it would surrender before you could say “Macron”.THE Lord Mayor of Sheffield is a ludicrous dingbat called Magid Magid who has been coughed up from somewhere deep in the bowels of the Green Party.Shortly before Remembrance Day he posted a publicity shot of himself online wearing a white poppy and a T-shirt saying “never again!”A good moment, then, to ask the vital question: Have you ever met someone wearing a white poppy who wasn’t a complete and utter moron We wear red poppies to commemorate the terrible loss of le in battle.People wear white poppies to commemorate themselves and their fatuous sensibilities.It’s called showing off.WAGES have risen at the fastest rate for almost a decade.They went up by nearly three per cent in the three months to September, compared to a year earlier – and about time, too. title: brexit deal purgatory leavers remainers
story: It’s quite a challenge, but let’s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EU’s rules — on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law — but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. Suppose we had to submit to a trade and tarf regime designed solely to benefit the other .I hope both sides could agree that such an outcome would be the worst of all possible worlds. And yet, that is where we appear to have ended up.First, under the transition, we shall explicitly be non-voting members for two years.As Brussels has spelt out with brutal clarity, the only change will be that Britain loses its Commissioner, its MEPs and its vote in Council.Then, under the backstop, that status, or something very like it, will be imposed on us in semi-perpetuity.Surely no one — Remain or Leave — can favour such an outcome.I have been arguing since polling day for moderation.I was prepared to accept any compromise, including European Free Trade Association and including Chequers, provided it restored the supremacy of our laws.But the purgatory that now beckons is surely, by any definition, worse than either staying or leaving.From the start, our objective was simply to reach a deal — any deal.Our negotiators, shell-shocked by the referendum result, approached the talks in a spirit of damage limitation.They never seriously contemplated walking away, and the other side smelt their desperation.To be fair, our officials were not helped by the noises coming out of Westminster.How would you expect EU negotiators to react when senior British politicians urge them to hang tough and force a second referendum We might view Tony Blair, John Major and Nick Clegg as has-beens but, believe me, they are seen in Brussels as men of influence.So we fell into a pattern. Britain would make some new concession in the hope of unlocking a deal.Then Brussels would pocket the concession and demand more and — incredibly — British Remainers would cheer.The UK agreed to hand over more money than was due accepted the EU’s absurd and illogical sequencing made an unconditional security guarantee offered to copy EU standards and promised not to be more competitive than its neighbours.Each time, the EU brusquely demanded “more movement”. Each time, Britain rushed to comply.Which brings us to where we are — facing colonial rule from Brussels, of the sort the EU imposed on Bosnia following the Yugoslav war.I am not one of those Brexiteers who half-favoured no deal all along.On the contrary, I was proposing moderation even before the vote, and have repeated that call many times since.But, paradoxically, our reluctance to countenance no deal has made such an outcome likelier.We have reached the point where the terms on offer are less attractive than either a World Trade Organization-based Brexit or a second referendum. This last point is critical.I suspect that two contradictory arguments will now be wheeled out before wavering MPs.Europhiles will be told that the deal, backstop and all, is better than “crashing out” on WTO terms.Conversely, Eurosceptics will be told thatthey don’t approve the deal, Parliament might vote to extend Article , thus imperilling Brexit.These two lines of argument can’t both be true, of course and, in reality, neither of them is.We’re invited to believe thatBoris Johnson and Jo Johnson, from opposite ends of the Brexit spectrum, both oppose the deal, it can’t be too bad. In fact, both Johnsons oppose it because it is a lamentable failure of statecraft.Boris was no Brexit headbanger: He came out for Leave only after the EU refused to give David Cameron any powers back.And Jo is no Remoaner: He has spent two years in Government trying to deliver a reasonable Brexit. If neither of them will back the deal, that tells us something.There is still time — just — to recover our position.As things stand, the backstop has no legal force.The moment it finds its way into a treaty, it will be binding. If any MPs oppose the current approach, now is their chance to act. There won’t be another.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: time for decades of eu lies to end
story: Britain is a eurosceptic nation. In the s, Ted Heath and Harold Wilson both knew we would baulk at belonging to a Common Market that robbed us of our national independence.So they hid its true purpose — “ever closer union”, leading to a superstate with one currency. The public was reassured our sovereignty would not be surrendered to any meaningful degree.The Tory and Labour leaders both knew this was a lie. But they kept quiet when signing us up in  and when holding the first referendum in .Voters were betrayed from the start. And the pattern was set.In  John Major signed the Maastricht Treaty, creating the EU, without risking the public vote that saw it initially rejected by the Danes and Irish.In  Tony Blair — who now shamelessly praises fork-tongued civil ­servants for hoodwinking eurosceptic ministers — feared he would lose a referendum on handing new powers to the EU. So he refused to hold it.His successor Gordon Brown, never big on honesty when a lie served him better, pretended this Lisbon Treaty was too insignicant to bother voters with.The EU is founded on deceit. “When it becomes serious, you have to lie,” says President Jean-Claude Juncker. Voters are bullied into reversing inconvenient referendums or denied a say at all.And so to Mrs May, the Brexit deal her Cabinet agreed last night and the revealing EU leak yesterday which makes crystal-clear Brussels’ intentions to keep us in its vice-like grip for ever.That plan being to lock us into its Customs Union for all time, unable to make our own trade deals, powerlessly swallowing its orders and obeying its rules.Our Government knows we cannot legally escape this central pillar of the EU — which we voted to “leave”, remember — without consent from Brussels that it will never give.This is not some minor afterthought, to be bargained away, which is why MPs rejected it in July. It is crucial to the reclaiming of our sovereignty which a .million majority including many Sun readers, voted for in .It is crucial to our post-Brexit prosperity. It looks crucial, too, to whether the deal lives or dies. Yet, knowing exactly what the EU intends for us, the PM still brazenly insisted yesterday that we WILL make our own trade deals.How, Mrs May  We cannot. You surely know it.Do not kid yourself no one is paying attention. The public has been sold a pup again and again. It has had enough.Come clean with Britain. This deal is not wholly without merit. But let us see it for what it is.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: david cameron prime minister brexit steve hilton

title: schoolgirl trapped grenfell tower 999 handler
story: Jessica Urbano Ramirez was one of the  people who died as a result of the horric blaze on June  last year.She fled her flat on the th floor before taking refuge along with others higher up the -storey tower block in west London.Complaining of smoke and fire below, Jessica repeatedly asked London Fire Brigade control room officer Sarah Russell: Please can you hurry up Details of her  call - which lasted almost an hour - were revealed in a -page transcript at a public inquiry today.Ms Russell had just one days training in dealing with fire survival guidancecalls when she took the operator job - a full eight or nine months before the Grenfell Tower fire.During the call she told Jesscia: They are hurrying up. Is there another room you can go into Jessica replied: No, can you hurry up please  Im begging you.Ms Russell told her: They are, theyre right below you. But you need to keep yourself safe.Giving evidence, the officer admitted she had no information that firefighters were on their way, but said she was trying to reassure the youngster.Counsel to the inquiry Richard Millett QC asked her: Did it occur to you that you had not yet assessed the security of the escape route and telling her that the crews were coming up, without having solid information to back that up, meant that you might be lulling her into a  sense of security Ms Russell said: At the time, no. It was based on what I would expect to happen, what should happen.It was more about comforting her and trying to get her through that situation and get the information .In a written statement Ms Russell said she was glad she had stayed on the call evenit was only to offer her a little support.After about an hour I could not get anymore response from her - only rasping sounds, then nothing, she said.Reflecting on that call, I felt completely helpless.When people are pleading with you, saying [they] do not want to die and I cannot physically do anything to help them - it is very hard.The information that Jessica had fled to a higher floor was not passed on to fire crews on the ground, who searched her flat but found no trace of the youngster.Ms Russell said that, not long after the call ended, she became aware the advice to callers had been changed from stay-put to attempt to evacuate.

title: boy excluded school braids

title: what men keep to themselves
story: Now, more than , blokes of ying ages have shared all — with a hi-tech robot called Harr-e, which toured the UK to get to the heart of fellas’ feelings.It follows a study, conducted for men’s care brand Harry’s that found men are three times more likely to confide in Articial Intelligence than humans.”They were quizzed on subjects ranging from what keeps them up at night and the state of their love le to what they think about their body.Here is what some were willing to open up about in the revealing tell-all that offers a fascinating insight into the minds of men.STUDENT, , Kent: “There have never been more ways to measure your success or failings as a man. story: The piles of earth, which are as old as the pyramids, cover an area bigger than Britain and are visible from space.The mounds are not nests but the product of a slow and steady excavation of interconnected underground tunnels, according to a study of soil samples.The insects deposited huge quantities of dug out soil to create around  million cone-shaped mounds, each about .ft  tall and .ft wide.Together the mounds cover an area of , square kilometres, signicantly greater than England, Scotland and Wales combined.And the termites activities over thousands of years produced enough excavated soil to fill Wembley Stadium , times over. At ground level, they are largely hidden from view among the thorny scrub caatinga forests unique to the semi-desert region - but they show up on Google Earth satellite images.Study leader Professor Stephen Martin, from the University of Salford, said: These mounds were formed by a single termite species that excavated a massive network of tunnels to allow them to access dead leaves to eat safely and directly from the forest floor.The amount of soil excavated is over  cubic kilometres, equivalent to , great pyramids of Giza, and represents one of the biggest structures built by a single insect species.The scientists collected soil samples from the centres of  mounds and used dating technology to estimate their age.The results, published in the journal Current Biology, showed the mounds were between  and , years old.Termite mounds have a complex inner structure with numerous shafts and tunnels that serve as a ventilation system for underground nests.The constructions investigated by the scientists are not abandoned ancient relics.Their builders, all members of the termite species Syntermes dirus, still inhabit large colonies incorporating as many as  mounds, the study found.Prof Martin added: Its incredible that, in this day and age, you can find an unknown biological wonder of this sheer size and age still existing, with the occupants still present.Many questions about the termite colonies remain unanswered, said the researchers.For instance, attempts to explore the colonies with a fibre optic scope had failed to locate a single royal chamber housing the termite queen.The mounds were also distributed in a strangely regular way that did not appear to be driven by aggressive encounters between neighbouring colonies.

story: According to the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Vaping , employers should provide designated indoor vaping areas - including in the Houses of Parliament.They want vaping to be more acceptable around the workplace with proper vaping policies for businesses and public places to be put in place in a bid to tackle misunderstandings about the practice.The group believes that guidelines for reasonable vaping etiquette should be drawn up and that all outside areas should be available to vapers unless theres a legitimate safety or professional reason to stop it.APPGV chairman Mark Pawsey said that Britains current anti-vaping culture created a  impression among the public that passive vaping was as harmful as passive smoking.Indeed, this lack of understanding was very evident in Parliament itself, a place many will look to for an example.There are only two designated vaping locations, and despite being a member for eight years, I still have no idea where either of these locations are, he said.Both of the sites are outside and given the size of the Parliament Estate could be a signicant distance away from an employee or visitors location, MPs stated.It comes after council bosses in Dundee banned staff from vaping anywhere during work hours - eventheyre off the premises.While the British Heart Foundation doesnt advise non-smokers to start smoking e-cigs, Public Health England estimates that theyre  per cent less harmful than regular cigarettes - thanks to the fact that they dont create toxic tobacco smoke.Hazel Cheeseman, Director of Policy for Action on Smoking and Healthtold The Sun: “Public health organisations like ASH and PHE have long said that we need clear policies that distinguish between vaping and smoking.When organisations treat them the same, without being clear that e-cigarettes are a much less harmful alternative, it fuels public misunderstanding and makes it less likely that smokers will switch and protect their health.Whether people choose to allow vaping inside the workplace will depend on inidual circumstances.But what is crucial is that employees understand that vaping is not as harmful as smoking and any restrictions are not about health but about courtesy in the working environment.A report by PHE published in  found that e-cigs were so much less harmful than smoking, that they could pave the way for the real game changer in regards to helping prisons go smoke-free.A project to get prisons in England to implement smoke-free policies is now fully underway, with vaping playing a critical role.Prior to the project starting, around , prisoners were buying tobacco.Today, prison canteens sell over , vaping protects to , prisoners - suggesting a signicant reduction in harm.According to Public Health Matters, . per cent of adults in England smoke tobacco. In prison,  per cent of people smoke.If vaping really is  per cent safer, that could see a massive reduction in the , smoke-related deaths we see in England every year.Daniel Pryor, Head of Programmes at the Adam Smith Institute told The Sun: Britain’s businesses should make it as easy as possible for smokers to switch to e-cigs, which are at least  per cent safer than cigarettes.The latest scientic evidence shows no risks from so-called passive vaping, so letting vapers use their devices considerately indoors is a no-brainer for public health and personal freedom.Not having to pop out for a puff in the pouring rain could make the dference between someone stopping smoking using an e-cig and their quit attempt ending in failure.And stopping could make the dference between living a long and healthy le, or dying early of cancer.The New Nicotine Alliancehas welcomed the Parliamentary report, with its chair, Sarah Jakes, saying: The Parliamentary estate becoming vape-friendly would send a strong message to other employers and venue owners that vapers should be encouraged, not harassed, and would help to educate the public that vapers are simply former smokers doing something that is good for their health.There are currently . million vapers in the UK, . million of whom have quit smoking entirely using e-cigarettes.This has contributed to the rate of smoking prevalence plummeting, but many smokers are still hesitant due to misperceptions surrounding vaping.More liberal workplace policies can have the dual benefit of correcting these misperceptions while also providing a more encouraging environment for vapers to prevent relapse, as well as for smokers considering vaping instead.Back in August, MPs called for e-cigs to be made free on the NHS as a key weapon in the health services stop-smoking arsenal.

title: fish and chip shop owner struggling to find anyone to employ says benefits system makes people workshy
story: Frank Suhadolnik, , runs Haughton Chippy in Darlington and has never had trouble hiring staff in the past.He recently invested £, to open a second chippie in the market town but cannot find people to staff the shop.The -year-old claimed Universal Credit – the controversial new benefits system - had turned Brits “workshy”.In a letter to The Times he said: “It has to have something to do with the benefits system.“People have to be looking for work to qualy for benefits. So they turn up to our interviews to say they’ve been looking and then leave us stuck.“We’re just ordinary people trying to make a living and we just can’t get anybody to work. It’s unbelievable.”The grandfather and his we Pamela, , had been forced to cover  shts a week to keep the chippie going.He said: “My we and I are very old. We don’t mind working but we never imagined that we would have to go back to work full-time”.Frank’s son Robert, , who manages the chippie, told the Sun Online confusion around the new benefits system had made it very dficult to hire staff.He said: “Our second shop opened last week on the other side of town. Weve been recruiting for the last three months. We had around  to  applicants, some were unsuitable but for the ones we tried to arrange interviews for, only  to  per cent came in.“We organised about  interviews a day but only one or two attended.“Then when they get through the interview stage and to a trial sht, which is fully paid, they confirm they are coming on the day about pm saying they’ll be here for the .pm sht but then nobody walks through the door. It’s a bit of a mystery.“That happened for  days on the trot. It takes the wind out of your sails. It’s been a bit of a nightmare. We wanted to open for lunch and evening six days a week but we’ve only been able to do that for Friday and Saturdays.“We’re still in a constant state of recruitment. We’ve got seven or interview organised for tomorrow. But are these people going to attend ”Robert said uncertainty about the new benefits system - which rolls six payments into one - was frequently mentioned by applicants.He told the Sun Online: “It has been mentioned quite a lot. They don’t know how it’s going to affect them and there’s no way of knowing how it will affect them until they are in work.“If they are offered more hours in work, it might mean their council tax element gets cut, for example. That seems to be a huge concern. They don’t know where they are going to be financially and it’s a constant source of stress.”Brits going on to the new system have said it pushes them into debt as they are forced to wait at least five weeks for their first payment.Yesterday one mum said shed been forced into prostitution to make ends meet while she waited.And claimants have said they dont know what money they will be getting from week so week - with some claiming they are reluctant to get a job in case their income changes.But new DWP boss Amber Rudd has vowed to fix the problems and said she would fight the Treasury for more cash.When you first claim Universal Credit you wont be paid any money until five weeks after you submit your claim, you will then be paid monthly.So,you need help to pay your bills or cover other costs while you wait for your first Universal Credit payment, you can apply to get an advance.You can apply for an advance payment via your online universal credit account or through your Jobcentre Plus work coach.If you get Universal Credit, you may be able to apply for a budgeting advance of between £ and £ - depending on your circumstances - to help pay for emergency household costs.Again, this MUST be repaid within a year and repayments will be deducted from your monthly Universal Credit payments - or via other meansyou no longer get universal credit.If you fail to meet your responsibilities or what you’ve agreed in your claimant commitment, your Universal Credit could be stopped or reduced - this is called a sanction.You can ask for a hardship paymentyou cannot pay for rent, heating, food or hygiene needs because you got a sanction.The hardship payment is roughly  per cent of the amount you were sanctioned by in the last month.Again, you will need to pay it back through your Universal Credit payments.If you’re having financial dficulties or you’re behind on your rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an alternative payment arrangement .Depending on your circumstances, you could get an APA to:You may also be entitled to discretionary housing paymentsyour Universal Credit payment is not enough to pay your rent - but this will depend on your council, so ask.Renters and homeowners may also be entitled to housing payment.Plus,youre struggling to pay your council tax bills you may also be allowed an up to  per cent reduction. Contact your local authority for more information.If youre struggling to pay for a food shop, you may be able to get a minimum of three days worth of food from a Trussell Trust food bank - there are around  of these across the UK.Contact your local foodbank to find out which referral agencies it works with in your area and how you can get a voucher.But Robert was eager to point out how hard working his loyal team was at the chippie.He said: “People working for us work very hard and take pride in their work and that’s indicative of British people. We have had staff for + years and we don’t tend to loss staff, most have been here for around five or six years plus.“But when it comes to finding new people, we really dont know what to do.”

title: tiger farm czech republic fur stock cubes
story: The secret raid - dubbed Operation Trophy - was the culmination of years of work by agencies working together across the Czech Republic.Sickened inspectors found one freshly killed tiger and a chest freezer stuffed full of rotting remains when they swooped on the lucrative operation in Prague.They later discovered that bones turned into stock cubes were worth up an incredible £ per gram - which is the equivalent of £, per ounce.Inidual claws ripped from the cats powerful paws are worth nearly £ and a full pelt can fetch up to £, on the Czech black market.The demand for traditional medicines containing tiger products was driven in part by the countrys Vietnamese population.Those involved in the operation now fear the discovery points to a wider problem in Europe, reports the .At a press conference, Robert Šlachta from the Customs Directorate uncovered more details about the horrying case.“The tiger we discovered was shot in the eye and in the neck, so that the skin would stay intact and could be sold on the black market, he said.The cooking of the tiger meat took five to twelve days and all parts of the animal, including the pelts, teeth or claws, were intended for commercial purposes.”The investigation - which started five years ago - was carried out in close cooperation with the Czech Environmental Inspectorate.Its head, Erik Geuss, says the illegal trade in tigers has rapidly become a growing problem in the country.“In recent years, we have observed an increase in the illegal export of tigers and other felines from the Czech Republic, he revealed.This is because there is quite a large Asian community living in the Czech Republic and there is a substantial demand for tiger products in that region.“There are currently around  tigers registered by CITES in the Czech Republic but only around  of them live in zoological gardens.And while tigers kept in zoos live to around the age of , those kept by private breeders only live around five years.”Pavla Rihova, the lead environmental inspector on the scene, said she had never seen anything like it.“I have been working for the inspectorate  years … but the situation there was really horrible, she said.If you can imagine: an old freezer, without electricity, full of meat and dead bodies, in the garden for two years. Absolutely incredible.”In a shed next to the house officers found a freshly killed tiger, shot through the neck so as not to damage its valuable pelt.In the same room was a heavy duty cooking pot on a gas hob, filled with the unidentied meat and bones of animals.The trail of evidence began in , when Czech customs inspectors found a bag of tiger bones in the van of a Vietnamese man.A few months later, the skeletons of two tigers were found concealed within a set of loudspeakers being exported to Hanoi.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mini home tiny house new york devasa
story: These images show the unfurnished interior of the  sq ft portable home, with its wood-led walls and floors, as well as stairs leading to the second floor.Other shots show the tiny home from outside in its normal guise and with the roof extended to allow access upstairs.The Devasa, as it’s known, is legally towable and once parked up and expanded, can sleep a family of four.On the first level there is a kitchen, a smallish living room and a bathroom, with the bedrooms on the second level.The Devasa’s roof is raised and lowered by four motorized screw jacks located on each corner.This can be done using a car battery via the towing bar but should the battery die or the motor fail, it is possible to operate the jacks manually.The Devasa is work of the family-owned house designers behind Tiny House NYC and is currently on sale for around £,.We are a family-owned-and-operated business based in New York City, says the company.Our mission is to provide financial freedom for those seeking to go tiny.The world has changed a lot since the great recession, and from that tragedy came the need for alternative solutions to combat rising home costs, debt and stagnant wages.Many see the tiny house movement as a lestyle. It is certainly that, and we believe it also allows people to take control of their lives.By empowering others, we hope to create a more affordable and sustainable world for today and the future.The portable tiny house measures . ft long and . ft tall when in the lowered position and  ft tall when raised, offering impressive . ft high ceilings upstairs.

title: speeding car near miss couple walking street
story: His split-second reaction saves their lives as the silver hatchback comes speeding towards them on two wheels before slamming into a wall.CCTV footage shows the couple walking happily together on what appears to be a shared footpath and cycle way.The woman seems unaware of the coming danger as the man suddenly reacts and leans towards her.He pushes her to the side just as the car races past their shoulders.It appears to strike the mans foot on the way before hitting the wall, spinning round and coming to rest with steam pouring from the engine.The man and woman can be seen staring in disbelief at the wrecked car following their brush with death.He then writhes in pain on the ground as she gets to her feet unscathed.The drivers condition was not known as video emerged of the November  crash - thought to be in Europe.Last year shocking dashcam footage showed a VW Golf drivers near miss as he span out of control into the path of a coach with  on board on the M near Oxford.Another terrying video showed a near miss between a van and a car on the M in Lanarkshire.

title: brexit britain four more years theresa may admits transition extended to 2022
story: The Prime Minister told businesses she couldnt guarantee that she wouldnt need to extend the transition period beyond the end of .She would only promise we would be out of the EUs rules by the next general election - not scheduled to take place until .Addressing business leaders today at the CBIs annual conference, Mrs May defiantly told her critics she was the one to deliver Brexit.But she could not guarantee them that they would be in a new relationship with the EU by  as planned.She told them: I am clear that we have got an implementation period through to the end of .But she went on: Within the Withdrawal Agreement there is an extension to that further, as an alternative to putting in place the backstop for Northern Ireland.Mrs May added that she doesnt want that to have to come into place but it was therea deal was not secured by then.I think it is important that in delivering for the British people we are out of out of the implementation period before the next general election, she stressed.It comes after EU boss Michel Barnier proposed a maximum of a two year extension to the window - which would keep Britain in the Single Market and Customs Union.That would be more than SIX years after Britain voted to leave in June .The final date, currently marked in the Withdrawal Agreement as “XX”, needs to be thrashed out by the UK and EU ahead of a summit to sign off the deal next Sunday.During that time we’ll have to accept free movement and pay substantial budget contributions estimated at £ billion a year.Most EU capitals agreed on New Year’s Eve  as a final end date for the transition at a meeting with Mr Barnier in Brussels yesterday.This morning Business Secretary Greg Clark said it could make sense to extend it for weeks or monthsneeded.He told Radio : It would be at our request and that would be a maximum period.If we were six weeks away from concluding a future economic partnership and agreeing that then it may make sense to extend the transition period.The Prime Ministers spokesperson said this morning: The Prime Minister has always been clear that the implementation period ends in advance of the next general election and that remains the case.Voters will be merciless towards a Government which has failed to extricate us by then.So it is jaw-dropping to hear the Business Secretary say the “transition period” limbo might need extending till the end of , after the June election that year.Theresa May says it’s “important” to be out before polling day. No kidding!If not, Leave voters will flock to a party committed to actually ensuring it happens.

title: jacob rees mogg brexit coup theresa may dads army
story: As their attempt to boot out Theresa May flopped due to a shortage of no confidence letters, today MPs said they were set to move on her after the vote on her Brexit deal.The Brexiteer ERG ringleader Rees-Mogg, who put his own letter in last week admitted that getting the total of  was showing to be quite dficult.When askedthe plot had gone a bit Dads Army he replied Ive always admired Captain Mainwaring.But he insisted that when it came to the letter total patience is a virtue, and reckoning time would come next month.And he stressed: Do  want to come with me or not  I may find that they dont or they dont do it today but when we get the meaningful vote.And fellow Rebel Steve Baker said: Its very hard to see those letters not beingshe loses the meaningful vote... I do think its now or never.Mr Rees-Mogg also argued that rebels had to move now - otherwise Mrs May might lead the Tories towards another catastrophic defeat.He said: I think it is now or the Prime Minister will lead the Conservatives into the next election.And getting the deal through on the back of Labour votes would split the party and the country, he added.Deep isions in the Brexiteer camp has harmed the coup - with anger that major figures including Priti Patel, Iain Duncan Smith and Sir Bernard Jenkin had not publicly backed the plot, even though they have trashed Mrs Mays deal already.The Sun revealed a bitter new row erupted as some accused others of trying to oust Mrs May because they want peerages.Senior Eurosceptics had warned that yesterday was the moment of truth for the PM as they urged more MPs to hand in their letters.Only  have gone public with them so far amid fears that toppling Mrs May could collapse the entire Government and let Jeremy Corbyn into power.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt warned overnight that it would risk the most appalling chaos and could even stop us from getting through to the other side of Brexit.THERESA Mays new plan to scrap the contentious Irish backstop using technology would not be enough to win over Brexit rebels, David Davis declared today.The ex-Brexit Secretary said the alternative arrangements proposal to keep the border open was a material movement forward.But he added: It isnt by itself enough.Mr Davis said plans for regulatory alignment in the future framework would to tie British industry to the EUs rules forever.And securing a free trade agreement with the EU is much, much more important than a customs union.Asked about plans for alternative arrangements to avoid having to use the backstop altogether - revealed in today’s Sun - Mr Davis said: There’s also the question about regulatory compliance as well and that is very important to businesses.We are likely to be in the lead in things like articial intelligence, genetics and so on. We cannot be a world leader in those industriessomebody  writes the regulations for us.Similarly, it is not just a Northern Ireland border issue that determines when we get out of a customs union, it is also the question of the customs arrangements that the government has proposed.Many people think this is either impossible or would take five or ten years to put in place. That is also unacceptable.His sentiment was backed up by MP Michael Fabricant, who said today: I shall be voting against [the deal] in the Division Lobby. Pen and paper not required. A botched coup will merely strengthen the Remainers.It was revealed this morning that Mrs May will fly to Brussels for afternoon tea with Jean Claude Juncker tomorrow as she desperately tries to seal off her hated deal.Today the PM got a boost from Bank of England boss Mark Carney as he came out in favour of her Brexit plan.The Bank governor told MPs he welcomed the transition arrangements in the withdrawal agreement.And he warned the chance of a No Deal outcome is uncomfortably high, adding that it would cause an economic shock across the UK and EuropeMeanwhile, this morning Mrs May faced down unhappy Brexiteers in her Cabinet for the first time since they reluctantly signed off her agreement.The Prime Minister hosted the weekly meeting in No with her recently reshuffled top team, following a string of high profile resignations last week which almost toppled her.The meeting took much longer than planned, and was said to focus on the future trade deal with the EU Mrs May will now hope to seal.Last night the so-called Pizza Club Plotters, who were due to meet to try and force her hand, backed down amid splits.Mr Gove is now said to want to draw up plans for a revised Brexit deal in the event that Mrs Mays agreement gets voted down in the Commons next month - but Ms Leadsom was keen to keep up the pressure on the PM ahead of this weekends crunch summit.But Brexiteer John Redwood tried to put pressure on the unhappy Brexit cabinet minister to quit, saying they would be better off resigning together than vote for the unacceptable agreement.EU leaders will meet this weekend in Brussels to likely sign, seal and deliver Mrs Mays hard-won deal.If they agree on it, it will go to the Commons for a crunch vote in the coming weeks.But the pressure will be ramped up today after the DUP fired another warning shot to the PM last night by siding with Labour on a key Budget vote.As part of the deal with the Northern Irish party, they agreed to vote with the Conservatives on all finance matters - but last night they abstained on every vote and even sided with the Opposition on one.DUPs Sammy Wilson told Newsnight: You’ve got to keep your side of the bargain, otherwise we don’t feel obliged to keep ours.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: babies sleep through the night baby sleep cycles
story: But when do babies start snoozing the whole night through  We take a look…There is a myth making the rounds that babies should sleep through the night from the age of  weeks.Not only is this extremely rare, it can also add extra pressure on parents who are desperate for a full night’s kip.In reality, a baby will start sleeping through the night from between six and nine months old.It is around the four-month mark that important developmental milestones can totally change the baby sleep game, meaning a full night’s sleep could be on the cards very soon.Also, it is worth noting that when we talk about babies sleeping all night, we dont mean that they will suddenly be out for the count for double-digit hours.What this actually means is that the baby will be less likely to wake up crying in the middle of night or needing a night-time feed for a stretch of five to six hours or more.While this doesnt necessarily mean that baby wont want to be fed, or be snuggled, it should indicate that they no longer need additional sustenance in order to make it through until their morning meal.Baby sleep cycles are very dferent to adult sleep cycles as babies need far more hours of rest than grown-ups.A newborns sleep cycle is quite simple and has only two stages – quiet and active sleep.It is also much shorter than an adult’s, with an average of - minutes for the first nine months, often even shorter.When a baby first falls asleep they go into active sleep, which is very similar to REM sleep for adults.During this stage, babies are also more likely to wake up.A newborn will spend about  per cent of his or her sleeping cycles in this stage, as opposed to an adult, with only  per cent.About halfway through a sleep cycle, the baby falls into quiet sleep, which is characterised by slower, rhythmic breathing, less movement and no eyelid fluttering.Quiet sleep is the end of the sleep cycle, which means that the baby will either wake up orto active sleep.Six to Nine Months  From six months onwards, babies develop more stages that resemble adults and gradually replace quiet sleep.The duration of their sleep cycles also en and the time spent in active sleep shortens.Until the age of at least a year, babies and infants will have a much lighter sleep than an adult.From about six months old, babies can sleep for longer stretches, but it can take a while for them to build to a solid, uninterrupted - hours’ sleep with no whimpering or wakefulness whatsoever.Once baby is around  to  months of age, getting too much sleep during the day may interfere with his night-time cycle and stop baby sleeping through the night.This is why, at this age, it becomes vital to gently wake them up from a prolonged nap.Experts suggest that a four-month-old baby should be awake for about three hours before bedtime.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kevin maguire theresa halt brexit
story: NewsopinionKevin Maguire: Theresa May has to halt the Brexit wheel trapMirror columnist Kevin Maguire says that while time is running out, anything is possible before March  – an extension, a referendum, a general electionShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  NOV NewsopinionTheresa May is trapped like a rat in a wheel "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUnless or until Theresa May calls out the Brexit elite’s liars she’ll remain trapped like a rat in a wheel. Running hard to avoid falling over is a bad choice for a Prime Minister who’ll know privately her unpopular, chaotic plan is a far worse deal for Britain than remaining in Europe. Surrendering sovereignty to minimise economic damage is May’s cowardly compromise. A braver PM would denounce forcefully the cost-free easy Britannia bonanza fabricated by fibbers Boris Johnson and Nigel Farage, then champion another referendum. The uncomfortable home truths about stockpiling medicines and food as well as troops on the streets put into perspective the Leavers’ mythical poundmillion a week saving promise on the side of a bus. Timid Theresa May doesn’t come clean because she’s afraid of insulting five Cabinet Brextremists organising against her including Michael Gove and a Liam Fox suddenly believing any deal’s better than no deal.  She might survive a no-confidence vote of Conservative MPs in the coming weeks. But May is not strong and stable. She is living to die another day and her botched plan is barely worth the name. So a sovereign Parliament gains a glorious opportunity to take back control next month. Jeremy Corbyn’s immediate task is to convince his Westminster waverers the choice isn’t May’s mess or accidentally crashing out of Europe without a leline. Tory Leaver Zac Goldsmith declaring he’d have voted Remain in place of May’s mayhem. Brexit paymaster Arron Banks said last Sunday he’d do the same. They are rats abandoning the Quitter ship. The , who marched in London for another referendum were mocked as the longest Waitrose queue in history yet Ukip MEP Patrick O’Flynn attracting just four people to his protest outside No  was another sign which camp has the momentum. Time is running out but anything is possible before March  – an extension before departure, a referendum, a general election. The only certainty is the future’s unpredictability.

story: NewsSpice use RISES after legal highs ban with drug  times stronger than in shopsThe synthetic cannabis was slapped with a crackdown in  - but an office Home Office review admits its use "has continued or increased"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe synthetic cannabis is accused of turning users into zombies"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDangerous Spice is still available despite the Tory legal highs ban - and use is even rising in some cases, a damning official report reveals. But a Home Office review of the Act says use of NPS, especially synthetic cannabis, in prisons has continued or in some cases increased. A London hospital study also found the number of patients with synthetic cannabis problems doubled from  to  a month.And the review noted that some synthetic cannabis samples in Manchester were up to  times stronger than what had previously been sold in head shops”. Overall the review found the open sale of NPS - previously known as legal highs - appears to have been largely eliminated.But it said the trade has shted underground to street dealers while  head shops have closed.Synthetic cannabinoids are no longer being sold in branded packets, and are now largely sold in clear snap bags, the review added.This may mean that users are now less aware of the substances that they are taking, which could also lead to greater harms.It added: Some areas of concern have remained or emerged since the Act, such as the supply of NPS by street dealers, the continued development of new substances, the potential displacement from NPS to other harmful substances, and continued high levels of synthetic cannabinoid use among the homeless and prison populations. There was an explosion in the popularity of NPS on the drug scene around a decade ago.  The drugs contain substances which mimic the effects of traditional illegal drugs like cocaine, cannabis and ecstasy. Ministers brought forward the legislation to crack down on NPS after they were linked to dozens of deaths. The Act came into force in May , creating a blanket ban on the production, distribution, sale and supply of psychoactive substances in the United Kingdom for human consumption. Offenders can face up to seven years in prison, while civil orders can be issued to shut down head shops and online dealers. One of the main aims of the blanket ban was to close off a loophole in the previous regime. The loophole meant new drugs appeared with a slightly altered chemical make-up almost immediately after the previous version was banned. But the review said this objective does not appear to have been achieved, pointing to indications the emergence of new NPS in the UK has not ceased.

title: high flying single mum 28
story: NewsHigh-flying single mum, , with six-figure salary reveals secret to her successBusinesswoman JoJo Graham, who has a two-year-old son, does one thing before the start of every new work weekShareCommentsByJessica WalfordChris kitching:,  NOV NewsJoJo Graham has told how she balances le as a single mum and a businesswoman"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA high-flying single mum and author who earns six figures has told how shes built a successful business while raising a two-year-old son. JoJo Graham says its incredibly tough to strike a happy work-le balance but its entirely possibleyoure very focused on your goals and extremely careful with your time. The -year-old business coach plans her weeks by the hour so she knows where she has to be and what she has to be doing at every precise moment. JoJo, who started a network marketing business at the age of  and used her son Noahs nap times to grow her company, told WalesOnline that you really can have it all but it might not feel like it.  She said: Being a single mum and running a business isnt easy. Getting the work le balance is also very dficult, but it is possibleyou are very focused on what it is that you need to do to make that happen. For me, I am very careful with my time. I have to run my weeks like a tight ship. Every Sunday I sit down and plan my week to the very hour. I know exactly what Im doing at every moment. From having a part-time job aged  to working through university, and quitting the only profession shes ever known, JoJo is one determined woman. But how has she managed it all  Growing up in Haverfordwest in Pembrokeshire, JoJo got a good set of grades at GCSE and A-level. She worked in a bank during the holidays, as well as working as a barmaid and cleaner. She continued working as she went to study business management at University of Wales Trinity Saint David in Carmarthen. After graduating, she moved away from home at the age of . The one thing that changed things for me was when I was working in my bank job and it was , and I went for a promotion which Id worked years to get, she said. Somebody  got it instead of me, it was the moment I realised I had to stop allowing other people dictate to me how much Im worth.  I had to go out there and create success myself. As scary as it was, starting a business and building a business was the only option for me to actually create that. Within three months, JoJo quit her bank job and set up a network marketing business at the age of . Remarkably, she had replaced her full-time income within six months. Then, she found out she was pregnant. With the clock ticking before she became a mum, it just motivated her to grow her business rapidly. She worked tirelessly right up until the night her little boy was born - and ed to work just two weeks later. As the main bread-winner for her family, when her baby was eight months old she decided to start another business coaching and mentoring. Its not easy running a business and having a baby. I did it all through nap time when he was sleeping, she said She went on to earn a six-figure salary in her first year and is now an author too, all while being a very proud single mum. Working with over  clients, JoJo is a successful business coach who also runs online classes and programmes to help other female entrepreneurs grow their businesses. She hopes to help one million women build their own successful businesses by . The mum-of-one also travels the globe, attending business retreats with her mentors. Next year, JoJo is running her own retreat in Santorini, Greece. Juggling it all isnt easy, but JoJo says she makes it work. Ive built my business to a point where I can afford a nursery two days a week, she said. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are mum days and I dont do any work. Noah goes to nursery two days a week, which is great because he absolutely loves it. It gives me that time to work on my business and stop for a moment. Being a mum, its important to just step away from your role as a mother. Even though its the most rewarding and the best job that you could have in the world, we have to remember that were also important andwe want to reach all of our goals, then we need to make time for that as well. I put so much pressure on myself at the age of  to have everything all sorted when, in reality, I was still so young. As long as I was moving just a little bit, then that would be okay. Can you really have it all  I think its a decision, she said. I think that you can have it all but it might not feel like it. You can have a great business, a great relationship but some things are priorities. If anyone feels like they cant accomplish things in le, theyve just got to decide that they can make it happen. The only person that will stop you doing it is yourself.

X” While Melanie Hinson said: “This is the strangest thing ever, how dangerous is social media these days! Hope Chloe is okay and the police act appropriately. That’s disgusting! X”.  Last night a woman at Linzi’s house, in Glasgow, declined to comment on the allegations. A university spokesman confirmed they were investigating the claims. He said: “The welfare of all University of Dundee students is treated with the ultimate importance. “We are aware of these claims and our Student Services team and the Dundee University Students’ Association is providing assistance to those affected.” Basra deleted her Instagram account earlier in the day and was unavailable for comment.
